noun.description: A permanent unit of an army typically commanded by a colonel and divided into several companies, squadrons, or batteries and often into two battalions.
examples: two or three miles inland a highly experienced artillery regiment had established a defensive position

noun.description: Rule or government over a person, people, or country.
examples: the powers of ecclesiastical regiment which none but the Church should wield

verb.description: Organize according to a strict, sometimes oppressive system or pattern.
examples: every aspect of their life is strictly regimented

verb.description: Form (troops) into a regiment or regiments.

origin: Late Middle English (in the sense rule or government): via Old French from late Latin regimentum rule, from regere to rule.
